values:
I'm giving these books away to anyone who wants them. Yes, even to you folks I've never met, or went to high school with. I'll mail them to you on my dime. The last time I did this I posted pics with the books, but that takes too long. So if you want more info or to see the cover click on the link. Drop me an email with your mailing address at caseynmiles(at)gmail(dot)com.

1000 Extra/Ordinary Objects - amazon link

Suspension

We entered silence
Before the clock struck

Red wine is caught between the crystal
And your fingers
The air solidifys around your mouth.
Once-wind has sucked the curtains in
Like fright, against the evening wall
Prepared for the storm     Before the room
Exhales    Your lips unfold.
Within their sudden opening
I hear the clock
Begin to speak again.

I remember now, with the filled crystal
Shattered, the wind-whipped curtains
Bound, and the cold storm
Finally broken,
How the room felt
When your word was spoken -
Warm
As the center of your palms
And as unfree.

Audre Lorde
from The First Cities, 1968.

This is a complicated issue for me. On the one hand I believe with every fiber of my being that those who commit violence against another person (usually women) should face stiff penalties (locked up and let the government figure out what to do with them). However, using the term "sexually dangerous" is way too ambiguous. 

The current popularization of the word "queer" is a reclaiming of a slur attached to people deemed perverted and dangerous to society - homosexuals, dykes, faggots, queens, hermaphrodites, transvestites. Fifty years ago "queer" marked a person "sexually dangerous." 

Why did the justices choose the word "dangerous"? Especially considering "danger" is a sexualized and vilified identity - the bad boy from the wrong side of the tracks; the bad girl who'll fuck you, dump you, then make you beg for more. Why not "sexually violent"? 

There's something not right about their choice of language. Something not right at all.

My back pain was caused by a kidney infection. A fucking kidney infection. Good goddess almighty! 

After 2 weeks of cry-my-eyes-out pain I finally got some relief today. I was starting to panic, starting to think my MS was flaring up. I went to an urgent care last Sunday and they gave me muscle relaxants and a narco pain med, neither of which provided any relief. I was in a fucking haze AND in pain. This week I put a call in to my neuro just in case, and made an appt at the campus clinic. 

The urgent care place didn't even check for a kidney infection, but the clinic did. Turns out I got some stuff floating around in my pee that indicated an infection. The PA that saw me was awesome. I really want her to be a dyke. She was chubby and matter of fact, and had facial hair and orthopedic shoes. I took to her right away. She hooked me up with antibiotics (and some diflucan), more muscle relaxants to take before bed, prescription ibuprofen, and an order for physical therapy. She was like, "WHY did they give you ultram? That doesn't make any sense. WHY didn't they test for a kidney infection?" And I was all "I dunno..." 

My back is ALREADY feeling better after 1 freakin' ibuprofen horse pill. ONE! What a fucking ordeal. I can't believe I wrote a final paper feeling like this.

Where to start? I've been in terrible back pain since Monday (it's Saturday). I shat a final paper between then and now, turned it in last night. I was hoping the back tension would just magically disappear. It hasn't. Which has brought me here to complain about it and reflect on how fucking hard this semester has been.

This has been one of the lightest workloads I've had since I started in Fall 2008, minus a few crunching deadlines. But what a fucking emotional hellhole. If I wasn't crying I was having anxiety attacks or oversleeping or procrastinating or just really mad. But I keep a pretty calm exterior, which I'm coming to learn is a gift.

What's next...I got a summer job in The Writing Center at MSU, which I'm actually extremely nervous about. And I'll continue working for CCC Online. I have intentions of exploring more this summer - going new places, taking long drives, hiking. Now if my back tension would just RELEASE.

My walk is more like a shuffle. 
You can describe me as slow and deliberate. 
Mistake maker. Day shaper. 
Enemy of tomorrow, foe of yesterday, 
friend of right now. 
But, really, simply hopeless. 
Dream reader. Map folder. 

april 21, 2010

and have been posting recently, which has inspired me to do the same. I miss this big open text box. I've gotten so used to Facebook status updates and Twitter's 140 characters. What if I have more to say than that? I have about 3 weeks left in the semester and my 2nd year of this master's degree will be over. For some reason this has been a really difficult semester - emotionally and mentally. I've been doing some really hard work on myself, and it shows itself through depression, lack of focus and motivation, headaches, and apparently anxiety attacks. But I feel good about the life work I'm doing. Speaking of work, I have a channel on Vimeo.com of my work on The Gender Project, which is a series of short documentaries about the lived experience of gender. This project is ongoing and will hopefully keep growing in the next few years. I've been presenting it at conferences and am in the very beginning of a major marketing push to get the project in people's minds, classrooms, and workshops. My next stop is the Computers & Writing conference at the end of May. I'll be displaying The Gender Project as an installation that will be up throughout the conference.
layers, from the bottom: bread, butter, balsamic vinegar, tomato, chopped basil, mozzarella. toasted in the toaster oven till the cheese browned a bit, just a bit.

So I've got some books I'd like to give away before I donate them in mass. See something you want email me your address and I'll mail it to you. Crank by Ellen Hopkins (young adult poetry story about meth) What Was Lost by Catherine O'Flynn (novel about dead end jobs and a missing girl) Jane Eyre by Charlotte Bronte (never read it, but a classic) Lullabies for Little Criminals by Heather O'Neill (started it but didn't finish) Angela's Ashes by Frank McCourt (a classic memoir) Marley & Me by John Grogan (hardcover, book about a dog) Memory Babe: A critical biography of Jack Kerouac by Gerald Nicosia (never read it) Walt Whitman: A Gay Life by Gary Schmidgall (never read it) Treasury of Favorite Poems (a thick book of "classic" poetry) [Couldn't find a pic.] So...if you want one of these books send me an email (caseynmiles(at)gmail(dot)com with your mailing address, or if you're local I'll bring it to ya.
Key: 1. username 2. favorite bands right now 3. draw a heart 4. favorite person of all time 5. recent favorite person 6. tag people

school: all consuming, drowning gender project: being theorized san francisco: bright conference: awkward queer theory: hot katie: angry chipmunk with a magic wand ruby: likes dirty underwear spike: victim of corporal cuddling dallas: all sass, no games emotions: sorta mostly maybe stable therapy: helpful job: cool lansing: love winter: over it spring: tease summer: fest... daydreams: scooters and cupcakes food: vinaigrettes and aiolis obama: dude, wtf? tv: lil' rounds v. adam lambert, college basketball bedtime reading: jPod by douglas coupland music: k'naan, quantic soul orchestra, mary j. blige

Hey! Someone I love had an abusive, fat phobic experience recently with a "doctor" and we're pissed off about it. Please comment below with the names of any fat-positive and fat-acceptance newsletters and information. We're going to send them to their office.

Please repost.

Add to original post: http://meaning-making.livejournal.com/59919.html

So I am presenting The Gender Project (the series of documentary shorts I made last semester) at this big-ass conference (C's) in SAN FRANCISCO! My presentation will be on Saturday, but K and I are flying out to Cali this Wednesday. We are also on spring break. In short...spring break in San Francisco. Yes, please! And I got a little kish-cash from my program. Wurd. Check my twitter feed for San Fran updates - twitter.com/soulsmiles. p.s. I thought my folk song was funny...I know that I can't sing, but I have passion!

Sitting at my cleanly cluttered desk. A half empty heart-shaped box of chocolates is next to me. I got it 75% off from Walgreen's last night. I'm working on my second cup of coffee, listening to Ani, thinking what to type next. 

My desk looks out a window, but the blinds usually stay closed because the neighbors house is about 10 feet away. I don't trust the Witnesses. 

I'm waiting for FedEx to deliver my medication. It comes packed in an inflatable cooler and ice packs because it has to stay refrigerated. So, I have to be home when they deliver it. It's the rules. 

I like Thursday mornings cause I get to sleep in, which just means I don't get up at 6:30/7 to take K to campus. She doesn't teach on Thursday mornings. I've always wondered when the transition from staying up late to getting up early would take place. Here it is. I am not a morning person, tho I've been getting myself up by myself since the 3rd grade (when I got my first alarm clock). If I could communicate with grunts and head nods in the morning I would. 

Ani Radio on Pandora is playing "Fast or Faster" by Bree Sharp. I love this song, and only know about it cause of Pandora, which is a fuckin' sweet web app. 

I haven't been on LJ in days, maybe a week. I try to give LJ a respect I don't give Facebook or Twitter. LJ is more important, more invested. Although I do enjoy the intimacy of Twitter. 

That's all I got.

capitalism is in control now, marketing engagement rings to men who love women and to women who love men. thus begins the back and forth, to and fro, passive aggressive, hint-dropping, mall walking, red-rose-buying madness. diamonds are dug by brown and broken hands recieving heavy coins in return. capitalism's pocket change. spike tv alternates commercial blocks with cage-fighting and engagement rings. round and round we go, spinning on a paradoxical axis. man. woman. right. wrong. black. white. up. down. yesterday. today. tomorrow. forever. 

friday, february 13, 2008

another conversation with the moon bouncing from star to satellite a whisper, a scream, a memorial sent floating floating away journal entries deciphered with a clock turn the dial back to another big sky, another conversation with the moon -cm, today

thinking about... - nationalism - a society's desire for heroes - love is as imperfect as I am, as uniquely beautiful. as rare. - code - xhtml and css. words as structure, typing to build, then design. code as creativity. - water conservation. i am starting a research assistant position this semester. i'll be working on a project designing a social network for water conservation groups within the Great Lakes region. my role is surveying these groups so that the social network will serve their needs - web 2.0 - rational vs. irrational thinking/thoughts/feelings

I don't considered myself an overly organized person, but I do enjoy organizing. While some of this winter break was spent seeing family and friends, Katie and I also resolved to organize! But first, I present Noshing New Years: Party of Two. Rather than digest another.huge.meal I made small bits to nosh throughout the evening. Me and cucumber cups filled with hummus and sprinkled paprika and lemon juice. Cucumber cups, Ms. Livingston's Bean Dip, sushi from the grocery (leftover sweets beyond). Katie's Noshing New Year's attire. Notice the handmade scarf! And here's my outfit, which was really based around the hat, and little miss R. Fruit. The first order of organization business was Ikea. We bought this huge.red.bookshelf! And to go along with the coke bottle crate arkansas flea market find I got some kitchen wall organization. And installed it by myself! Katie started her collection of green babies with these little Ikea tropicals. We also hit up Homo Depot. I made this coat rack! (2 feet piece of 2x4, gate latch, and coat hooks) I also hung these shelves in the closet. We got pegboard for Katie's sewing room but haven't installed it yet. Katie also bought a vintage sewing machine cabinet from Lansing's own Dicker & Deal (with Kenmore sewing machine) to use as her desk space in the living room. Alas, I do not have a pic of it. I do, however, have pics of Katie's new bird feeder... ...and this is a neighborhood squirrel acrobatically stealing the bird food! (it was only a matter of time) Katie also rescued another new green baby. We named her Sandra. Have I mentioned that it's snowed a lot this break. Lucky for me Katie recently discovered she likes shoveling, and I don't object to her passion. And finally, here are some obligatory pet photos. Second semester starts tomorrow. I feel rested, prepared even. I'm ready to get this semester started and see where it takes me.< /cliche>

Some of this story can only be told in pictures, and some only in words. My first semester of grad school ended with a shot out of a cannon. I spent the first week of winter break floating, unaccustomed to having nothing to do. I cooked... chicken & dumplings beef stew & cornbread (from trader joe's) ...and decorated for the holiday. And then "having nothing to do" turned into "there isn't enough time in the day." I decided to hand-make most of the holiday gifts I was giving this year. I painted stencils, made magnets, and made baked goods. banana nut bread (I've been told it's the best ever...twice!) cookies! - oatmeal chocolate chip and peanut butter kisses the mess... By this time Katie was coming out of the post- first-semester float too. katie's dog walking outfit This was our first holiday season we've been able to spend together. First stop, Trenton for christmas eve and morning. I was so grateful to be invited and I thoroughly enjoyed the time I spent with Katie's family. They are all so warm. And Katie's mom was eager to get me "hammered" and fill my belly. Second stop, Farmington Hills for Christmas with my family. the stocking I've had since birth: We hit the road Friday morning for Arkansas. What should've been an 11 hour trip turned into 16 hours because we drove through an ice storm. But we did find time to stop for the Road Trip Champion Breakfast. McDonald's biscuit and a hash brown And then there was fog. But we finally made it to Paragould, AR, the city my grandparents live in. From left: Grayson (my sister), my mom, my pappaw, my mammaw, and me. Four generations filled my grandparents house on Saturday. We ate the way southern folk eat, we visited, and we laughed. my cousin erica and me my second cousin devin and my sister grayson my second cousin granger my second cousin cedric and my cousin denise (cedric, granger, and devin's mom) For the last few years I've gone to Arkansas by myself - without Katie. But this year she came too. We played "roommates," going back into the closet for a couple of days. It was a sacrifice we both decided to make. I am so glad she got to meet my family! We managed to find time to drive around the town and visit a flea market! Before we knew it we were driving back to Michigan, leaving "god's country" in our rear view...
A screenshot of my laptop's desktop - my google gadgets, rocketdock at the bottom, and a jaded christmas wallpaper.

The last person in our house to get some Midol literally shredded the plastic off the pack.



whuddn't me.

This morning I sent my last final project of the semester off to the professor. Which means... I'm done with my first semester of grad school! Wow. I made it. I didn't fail quit panic or freak out. The documentary project I've been working on the last two months was a huge success. It has been altered from a linear-based documentary film to a web-based collection of gender stories, which will expand the meaning of gender AND documentary. I'm excited and humbly intimidated to get this project off the ground. But first, winter break. I have plans for cleaning, baking, organizing, IKEA, poetry readings and reading poetry, the holidaze, and not doing any schoolwork.
Send your own ElfYourself eCards

from <lj user="rearviewmags">

1. Wrapping paper or gift bags? Wrapping paper, preferably from something around the house. 

2. Real tree or Artificial? All my life we had a real tree, and then when my sister and I lived together we got a real one too. But, my lord were those needles hard to clean up! So...I get the artificial vibe. Currently, I have a little foot and a half tall fake tree. I got it for, seriously, two dollars. 

3. When do you put up the tree? It has varied over the years. Sometimes it's a mad dash the day before Christmas, other times it's around Thanksgiving. 

4. When do you take the tree down? WELL into January. 

5. Do you like eggnog? No, no, and no. 

6. Favorite gifts received as a child? Gosh...I don't remember a "favorite." I do remember waking up to a lot of our gifts set up and in working order. It was like waking up to a toy store! 

7. Hardest person to buy for? Probably my mom. She's a lady who takes care of herself. 

8. Easiest person to buy for? Katie, cause she makes it easy. 

9. Do you have a nativity scene? Hahahaha...no. Tho I could make a really offensive one. Hmmm...

10. Mail or email Christmas cards? Mail, if I get around to it. I usually find a humiliating picture of myself and print it on a lot of sheets of paper, then stick it in an envelope with a non-religious holiday greeting. 

11. Worst Christmas gift you ever received? Anything pink. Actually, I am remembering a bright pink sweatsuit with a built-in vest that my grandmother gave me when I was a kid. 

12. Favorite Christmas Movie? Straight up, Home Alone. 

13. When do you start shopping for Christmas? I usually pick a weekend between Thanksgiving and Christmas to get it all done. But this year the semester has to end before I can even think about it. 

14. Have you ever recycled a Christmas present? Yes. 

15. Favorite thing to eat at Christmas? At my mammaw's - Scalloped Chicken (which isn't scalloped at all. It's this long process that involves rending chicken fat. But fuck me is it delcious). And then, um, I have my way with the sweets. 

16. Lights on the tree? Yep! Even my little guy will get some lights. I prefer the variety of colored lights. Katie does not. 

17. Favorite Christmas song? Classic - Winter Wonderland. Otherwise - Wonderful Christmas Time (yes, the one by Wings).

18. Travel at Christmas or stay home? Nowadays we stay home for the actual Day, and travel to Arkansas either the weekend before or after. After my parents got divorced and we moved to Michigan, my sister and I always spent Christmas with my dad. 

19. Can you name all of Santa's reindeer's? Yes, I can. 

20. Angel on the tree top or a star? Star! We had to retire the star we've had since we were kids. But we got a new one. It lights up. But it's not the same. Ho hum. 

21. Open the presents Christmas Eve or morning? Morning! "The sooner you go to sleep the sooner morning will come." - my Nena

22. Most annoying thing about this time of the year? The frickin' Christmas songs on the radio after Halloween (I agree!)

23. Favorite ornament theme or color? Just throw it all on the tree! 

24. Favorite for Christmas dinner? Something with easy clean-up. 

25. What do you want for Christmas this year? An iPod Touch, 2nd Generation. 

26. Who is most likely to respond to this? Grayson!

Kuala Lampur, Malyasia - Yoga is forbidden Malaysia's top Islamic body fresh from banning tomboys issued an edict Saturday that prohibits Muslims from practicing yoga, saying that element of Hinduism in the ancient Indian exercise could corrupt them. That National Fatwa Council's chairman, Abdul Shukor Husin, said many Muslims fail to understand that yoga's ultimate aim is to be one with a god of a different religion - an explanation disputed by many practitioners who say yoga need not have a religious element.

Saturday mornings start early these days. Out of bed hours before the double-digits of the day begin. Pee, brush my teeth, make coffee, find the paper on the front yard. Messy-haired and bra-less I take a seat on the couch, clear the coffee table and spread out the paper. Take that first glorious sip of coffee, and breathe. I have learned a few things this semester. I've learned that I really have to say what I mean, but not necessarily mean what I say. That meaning can come later. I have learned that I define what is meaningful, that sometimes I have to take myself seriously. I've learned how hard that is. I've learned that love bends, and the bend in the curve is terrifying. I've learned we built strong roots at the beginning; and I am thankful for them now. I have learned that I am not alone; yet I have seen loneliness rise from within. I feel alive, in the sense that I feel my pride with my pain - intensity.

FINALLY got to spend some time with my dear friend Maureen today. Mo, Katie, and I went to the Detroit Urban Craft Fair, which was held at the Fillmore (formerly State) Theater. It was a beautiful location, a perfect melding of cool crafts in this ornate theater. I bought a tin of herb+ginger Berry Fruity loose leaf tea and a couple of letterpress postcards from Rar Rar Press. I ALSO snagged an interview with Maureen for the documentary I'm working on. She had some really great insights and I'm looking forward to getting into the editing process! Last night I had a couple of folks in my program over for dinner, wine, and interviews. I was actually really nervous, but after a glass of wine I loosened up and just had a conversation and listened. I felt unusually comfortable behind the camera. 10 pm really snuck up on me tonight.

Got my eye on Prop. 2 and a belly full of ice cream. Waiting for "the speech" and this little patriot is off to bed. 6:30 am mornings almost can't compete. But alas, I wait... Peace and love, and I do mean peace and love tonight.
Wow. I am crying. Breathing a sigh of relief. In awe (a little bit) of the people of this country. January 20, 2009 - looking forward to it.

I've been keeping a close eye on Prop 1 (Medical Marijuana) and Prop 2 (Stem Cell Research). Freep.com is calling a win for YES on Prop 1, which means folks now have access to a form of relief they could only come by illegally.
I feel it is safe to start checking out Comedy Central.
The CNN Electoral Map Calculator is kinda fun.

The "CNN Projection" chime is gonna get old pretty soon. But...yes! Pennsylvania! yes! Michigan following through! Democratics retain control in the Senate! Florida is looking...good? I have CNN.com set up with the "Your Races" box. I'm only watching Prop. 1 and Prop. 2 though cause that's all I *really* care about. Bowties & Balls was supremely delicious. Not only was this a funny meal to make for Election Night, but it's also my first foray into producing a meal from knowledge and know-how, instead of following a recipe. This is my first election being fully digitally connected. I got CNN on the TV, my browser has 5 tabs - email, lj, facebook, twitter, and cnn.com. I'm wondering which tv person is gonna lose their voice first. And who's got a flask hidden under the desk?
Why, oh why, is Soledad O'Brien wearing those shoes??? The dyke in me shudders.
don't really like calling hillary a "soldier."

The Bowties and Balls are in the oven. CNN is my channel of choice tonight. I am a fan of their Magic Wall, mainly because I watched a video in one of my classes this semester about that technology and its creator. And Wolf Blitzer's name is an animal, and that's...kinda...interesting.

While Katie and I were waiting in the U-Scan line at the grocery store tonight we encountered two young ladies in front of us. They were bottle-blonde, unusually tan for November in Michigan, and wearing McCain/Palin stickers on their ass and thighs. They were buying a 6-pack of Mike's Hard Lemonade, and talking between themselves about their stickers. I heard a grumble about "hard work." And then, these words actually came out of one of their mouths: "Whatever. I want to stay rich." I might be posting a lot tonight. I am feeling the desire to document this night. It's historic.

Gah! I'm so NERVOUS to get the results tonight! It took me twice as long to read an article for class tonight, which starts at 5. Why, oh why, do I have class on Election Day? Interestingly enough, my class is WRA 415 and my ballot number was 415 - a lesson in civic duty? call it a day? skip class? If only I was so bold. I have planned an Election Night feast. I am calling it Bowties and Balls: Politics and the Patriarchy. I am making a spinach and cheese bowtie pasta bake and oven-baked meatballs.
I am watching Born in Flames right now. It is definitely going in my top 10, maybe even top 5, maybe.

Apples and Funky Pumpkins
......bliss......
Have some religious rhetoric with your cider and donuts!
Making friends...
The Apple of My Eye
Park bathrooms are safer with my gender identity than gas stations. But the question still remains...
We stopped for a picnic.
And came across some interesting places.
We also found a covered bridge...
...and beautiful fall colors!
It was a great day.
Katie's response to me when I apologized for being uncharacteristically talkative, "No, babe, you're not talkative...you're lonely." I am. I miss her. Grad school stole her brain/heart/soul.

Any Tweeters out there? Follow me - my username is soulsmiles. I am in the very beginning stages of producing a documentary about the difference between "gender" and "sex," and why the distinction isn't used correctly more often. I am hoping to present it at the Feminism(s) & Rhetoric(s) conference next fall, which my program is sponsoring. The impetus for this project is an assignment for my Multimedia Writing class, but I am seeing its production go beyond (waaaay beyond) this semester and become a huge piece in my portfolio. I am making a detailed plan and schedule right now, as well as doing research and stocking archival footage available via the public domain (www.internetarhcive.org). I will also be conducting interviews, which is probably the most anxiety invoking aspect of this project. But I have a list of very (very very very) smart people I hope will lend their voices to this documentary. So, don't be surprised if an email shows up requesting your participation. Just sayin'. In my other class, Digital Rhetoric, I'm supposed to be creating a viral video in the next couple of weeks. I'm considering personal humiliation right now. People love to see other people make damn fools of themselves. Have you ever seen me lipsynch in the car? At the mall? In a park? Tomfoolery! Classes seem to be going well, though I still feel like a rowboat in the middle of the ocean.

first, find a booth upstairs close to a power strip
set coffee and baked good down on table
heave backpack off and open
remove laptop power cord, headphones, nalgene
remove laptop and set in desired position on table
plug cord into power strip
plug into computer
remove cellphone from pocket
sit down and slide across booth
position coffee, water, and cellphone to right
baked good to left
open laptop monitor
write and post weird lj entry

I picked up some Michigan-grown tomatoes yesterday at the City Market (along with a bag of Michigan apples and an eggplant for Eggplant Parmesan tonight). I am slow roasting the tomatoes with garlic, onion, fresh thyme, and oregano right now for the tomato sauce of tonight's Eggplant Parm. Our house smells amazing. There are loads of laundry being spun and lots of studying being done. What a rhymtastic sentence that was. I just burned a couple of cd's for my friends. And have plans to make Oatmeal Chocolate Chip cookies this afternoon. The TV is off and the music is on - so far we've gone through the new Ani cd (Red Letter Year), Good Dog Bad Dog by Over the Rhine, and right now we're listening to an awesome downtempo compilation called Cosmic Funk. Ruby is in her condo (the mudroom) and is NOT whining (so far). Really the only thing missing from a content life right now is seeing Mo and John. I miss you guys!
Share your pics of Katie's locks if you got 'em!

No, not (ala)Bama, Oh-Bama. 

Didn't make it up to the rally yesterday, but I DID watch a live videocast online. The best part about that was I wore nothin' but my bathrobe. 

I had a major FAIL moment during my presentation last night. Basically the Powerpoint I spent two days working on didn't launch because my new computer has the most recent version of the program. I go to load my presentation on the user experience of the Righteous Babe Records website and it's not there. I had to wing it. 

And then, THEN!, at the end of my presentation my professor says to the class, "This website has a major problem. Can anyone tell me what it is?" Mr. Smartypants (who's actually really smart and funny, but still a smartypants) raises his hand and says, "Blah blah blah, the design is different on some pages." Which I FAILED to pick up on. Thanks, buddy. My Powerpoint FAILS and then I FAIL. More failure please! 

In lieu of all these awesome failures I am taking the day off from school today, which just means I'm not studying or doing any homework. Eff it! Instead, my love and I are gonna head into Old Town, snap some pics of Katie's lockies by the river, hit up the city market for fresh produce, and stroll around Joann Fabrics. Actually, Katie usually has to drag me around JoJo's. God I get bored in there.
